bestBHT.bht: Paul asks for prayers to boldly declare the Gospel and fulfill his apostolic calling by making it manifest as he ought. Even though imprisoned, he believes that a door for the word can be opened and that he can preach with undaunted confidence, advancing the Gospel. He seeks to reveal the mystery of Christ with boldness, intrepidity, and freedom of mind, not striving to please men or fearing their reproaches. Paul desires prayers to speak the Gospel fearlessly, making it known in its fullness.

Henry Alford: If that might be so, the door opened, &c.,—then he would make it known as he ought to do—then he would be fulfilling the requirements of that apostolic calling..."
Certainly this is the meaning,—and not, as ordinarily understood, that he might boldly declare the Gospel in his imprisonment.
This second that gives the purpose of the previous verse, not the purpose of his being in bonds.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Paul asks their prayers for his release as if it were the 'only' way by which he could 'make it (the Gospel) manifest' as he ought."
A door for the word could be opened, and was opened, for its manifestation, even while he remained imprisoned.
Philippians 1:13, written somewhat later in his imprisonment, clearly shows that 'a door for the word' could be opened, and was opened, for its manifestation, even while he remained imprisoned.
Albert Barnes: That I may make it manifest ... - Notes, Ephesians 6:20.
Marvin Vincent: That I may make it manifest [ινα φανερωσω] . Compare speak boldly, Ephesians 6:20. That connects with the clause that God - Christ.
John Calvin: He desired for himself an undaunted confidence, such as befits the majesty of the gospel.
A rule is in like manner prescribed to us, not to give way to the fury of our adversaries, but to strive even to death in the publication of the gospel.
Philip Schaff: They should pray that he might preach; but he should preach in order to make manifest the mystery of Christ.
‘as I ought to do it (namely, freely and unrestrainedly), so as best to advance and further the gospel’ (Ellicott).
Archibald T. Robertson: Wonderful as Paul's preaching was to his hearers and seems to us, he was never satisfied with it."
John Gill: It being a mystery, a secret, which was hid in God from everlasting.
The apostle was desirous of making it manifest in a ministerial way.

With all constancy and certainty, with all boldness and intrepidity of soul, and freedom of mind; not seeking to please men, aiming at vain glory, and popular applause, or being afraid of their faces, menaces, and reproaches.

He asks for prayers not only for his release, but also for the opportunity to speak the Gospel fearlessly, making it known in its fullness to all.
